channel.title: IBM Research
channel.description: At IBM Research, we’re inventing what’s next in AI, quantum computing, and hybrid cloud to shape the world ahead.

item.title: An 'undo-and-retry' mechanism for agents
item.description: IBM and University of Illinois IBM Research and University of Illinois propose a Ctrl-Z feature for agents that could help to resolve IT issues faster

item.title: The future of AI is in your hands
item.description: Small models and powerful personal devices are poised to upend how we use AI.

item.title: Scaling for quantum advantage and beyond
item.description: IBM® lays out the groundbreaking advances in algorithms, hardware, and software that will empower our community to achieve quantum advantage together.

item.title: Building quantum computers with advanced semiconductor fab
item.description: An inside look at how IBM® is using state-of-the-art 300mm semiconductor fabrication technology to build the future of quantum hardware.

item.title: The Coherence Times: an IBM Quantum podcast
item.description: New weekly podcast introduces you to the thought leaders, researchers, developers, and technologists building the future of quantum computing.

item.title: Leading the way in open Earth observation AI
item.description: Understanding our planet has never been more critical. From insurance and finance to logistics and agriculture, countless industries need reliable insights about how the Earth behaves. Foundational AI is opening unprecedented possibilities for how we observe and measure our world — and IBM Research, together with NASA, the European Space Agency and other partners — is at the forefront of this transformation.

item.title: Discovering a new quantum algorithm
item.description: How group theory and the non-Abelian Fourier transform open the door to new quantum computing research applications.

item.title: Boost your agents: Introducing ALTK, the open-source agent lifecycle toolkit
A tribute to the art and science of generative AI
item.description: IBM researcher and artist Mauro Martino explains AI's inspiration and contributions to his latest work of art.

item.title: What's new at IBM Quantum Q3 2025
IBM is expanding open-source AI model training and inference
item.description: At PyTorch 2025, IBM showed off the new open-source AI software tools that are redefining possibilities for a multi-AI accelerator world.

item.title: Qiskit C API enables new end-to-end quantum + HPC workflows
item.description: Build end-to-end quantum + HPC workflows as a single application written natively in popular HPC programming languages like C++ with our new demo.

item.title: Release News: Qiskit SDK v2.2 is here!
item.description: Technical release summary for Qiskit SDK v2.2, including updates on the new end-to-end quantum + HPC workflow demo enabled by Qiskit's C API.

item.title: Introducing Thinking-in-Modalities with TerraMind
Toucan takes tool-calling to a whole new scale
item.description: Open-sourced by IBM and UW, Toucan is designed to improve how agents accomplish real-world tasks.

item.title: Introducing CUGA: The enterprise-ready configurable generalist agent
Introducing IBM's new toolkit for AI steering
item.description: AI Steerability 360 lets you build and test pipelines for customizing LLM generation.

item.title: How the Basque Country became a leader in quantum computing
item.description: In a few short years, the Basque Country has established itself as a global player in quantum computing. Here’s how.

item.title: New tiny AI models for Earth observation
item.description: IBM Research and partners unveil new versions of Prithvi and TerraMind that are small enough to run on a smartphone.

item.title: Building the IBM Spyre Accelerator
item.description: IBM Spyre is becoming available for IBM z17, Power11, and LinuxONE 5 systems. Here’s how its journey began in the AI Hardware Center at IBM Research.

item.title: IBM and partners open-source a new AI model for monitoring Earth’s oceans
item.description: Granite-Geospatial-Ocean can be used to monitor the health of marine ecosystems and the oceans' uptake of carbon.

item.title: New AI model finds railroad defects before they’re critical
item.description: A new AI model detects and tracks rail maintenance issues before they can cause problems, freeing up skilled workers from tedious inspections.

item.title: IBM and Vanguard explore quantum optimization for finance
item.description: Variational quantum algorithms for portfolio optimization.

item.title: IBM's time-series foundation model reaches #2 on GIFT-Eval
item.description: The model uses a state space architecture to outperform time-series models at least 20 times bigger.

item.title: How AI alignment differs from AI steering
item.description: IBM Fellow Kush Varshney explains the difference, and provides an update on IBM's latest work to mitigate the safety risks around generative AI.

item.title: HSBC explores algorithmic trading with IBM quantum computers
item.description: Researchers deliver first-known empirical evidence that quantum computers could soon solve valuable problems in algorithmic bond trading.

item.title: IBM and BharatGen collaborate for India's AI needs
item.description: Using the multimodal AI and LLMs BharatGen is working on, it will work with IBM to build the unique tools needed to best serve Indian language speakers.

item.title: Building software for quantum-centric supercomputing
item.description: Explore open-source tools that IBM and its partners are creating to enable seamless integrations of quantum and classical high-performance computing resources.

item.title: Improving AI agent reliability with BeeAI
item.description: The RequirementAgent from the BeeAI Framework is an innovative approach that provides the reliability needed for production scenarios made simple.

item.title: Register for the new Qiskit v2.X developer certification
item.description: Updated Qiskit developer certification exam tests your ability to perform essential quantum computing tasks with the latest version of Qiskit.

item.title: IBM researchers win prestigious European grants
item.description: Ghazi Sarwat Syed and Gregor Seiler add to IBM Research’s strong history with European Research Council grants.

item.title: Ado: The accelerated discovery orchestrator
item.description: The new platform for computational experiments at scale.

item.title: IBM further strengthens Granite for enterprise deployment with HackerOne
item.description: IBM is partnering with HackerOne to offer a bug bounty program for Granite, with up to $100,000 in bounty payouts available. The objective is to identify successful jailbreaks of Granite models deployed in enterprise-like settings with guardrails enabled, as businesses look to scale their AI workflows.

item.title: Introducing Surya, a new heliophysics foundation model
item.description: IBM and NASA open-source a new AI foundation model for the Sun that could change how we look at solar flares.

item.title: Can AI generate truly novel algorithms?
item.description: A decades-old approach to measuring algorithmic complexity could provide a window into better understanding how AI systems compute.

item.title: Towards a generative future for computing
item.description: IBM is exploring a future where generative AI isn’t limited to what’s in the prompt window.

item.title: Updates on the IBM Quantum Credits program
item.description: Apply today for free access to cutting-edge IBM quantum capabilities

item.title: IBM's AI Hardware Center is building tomorrow's processors
item.description: A look inside the group developing full-stack solutions to AI’s unique computational requirements.

item.title: IBM's Wei Sun is an expert at navigating life's trade-offs
item.description: Her research focuses on applying operations research to real-world problems. We spoke to her about OR, AI, and what’s next.

item.title: Opening a new era in algorithmic development
item.description: IBM Research is turbocharging algorithm development for a world with quantum computing and AI.

item.title: IBM Storage Scale delivers real-world performance: an in-depth analysis
Introducing Relay-BP
item.description: IBM® researchers have devised the fastest, most accurate decoding algorithm for quantum LDPC code error correction.

item.title: Debugging LLMs to improve their credibility
item.description: New tools from IBM Research can help LLM users check AI-generated content for accuracy and relevance and defend against jailbreak attacks.

item.title: Simulated steps help AI learn how we walk for neurology
item.description: IBM and Cleveland Clinic show how synthetic gait data may unlock the future of neurological disease monitoring.

item.title: Applications are open for the Qiskit advocate program
item.description: Join a community committed to shaping the future of quantum computing.

item.title: What's new at IBM Quantum
item.description: A roundup of the latest and greatest from IBM Quantum®.

item.title: Can LLMs learn social skills by playing games?
item.description: A new open-source framework, TextArena, pits large language models against each other in competitive environments designed to test and improve their communication skills.

item.title: Apply to host an event at Qiskit Fall Fest 2025!
item.description: Sign up for one of the informational sessions taking place 14-19 August to get a chance at hosting your very own Qiskit Fall Fest event.

item.title: The dawn of quantum advantage
item.description: We predict the quantum community will uncover quantum advantage by the end of 2026, but how will we know when it's arrived?

item.title: How IBM’s Kush Varshney became an iconic 'test' photo
item.description: The IBM Fellow reflects on copyright law, generative AI, and how he became the face of the modern camera man

item.title: Moderna and IBM use quantum computing to model mRNA
item.description: IBM® and Moderna achieve one of the largest and most advanced variational executions ever realized on quantum hardware.

item.title: USC researchers show exponential quantum scaling speedup
item.description: New study confirms algorithmic speedup for an oracle-based mathematical problem, showing the potential for algorithm development to enable quantum advantage.

item.title: Meet AssetOpsBench, IBM's first industry 4.0 benchmark
item.description: Developers can use the open-source benchmark to build, evaluate, and improve asset management agents in realistic industrial scenarios.

item.title: Access the latest research with Qiskit Function templates
item.description: Qiskit Function templates are realistic code examples that speed up development via modular pipelines for building high-quality, reusable quantum workflows.

item.title: New IBM Quantum Learning expands open-access content library
item.description: IBM Quantum Learning is moving to the new IBM Quantum Platform, and to celebrate, we’re releasing new content for Open Plan users.

item.title: IBM is adding AI agents to Maximo Application Suite
item.description: The goal is to help enterprises move from a fixed maintenance schedule for their equipment to condition-based servicing that could be more cost effective.

item.title: Release News: Qiskit SDK v2.1 is here!
item.description: Technical release summary for Qiskit SDK v2.0, including updates to the Qiskit SDK's C API.

item.title: Apply today to IBM Quantum Developer Conference 2025
item.description: Preview the hardware and software that will power the first demonstrations of quantum advantage at the second-annual IBM Quantum® Developer Conference.

item.title: Lossless compression tailored for AI
item.description: ZipNN, IBM’s new open-source compression library, can cut AI storage costs by a third, and speed up transfers by up to 150% — with zero performance loss.

item.title: IBM Research Dublin moves onto Trinity College's campus
item.description: The new lab is at the heart of Ireland's oldest university, and will focus on AI and quantum research.

item.title: IBM Granite Vision tops the chart for small AI models
item.description: The latest Granite vision model recently came in second on the OCRBench leaderboard, and is the best-performing small model on the chart.

item.title: Watsonx Code Assistant for Z is the Rosetta Stone for COBOL
item.description: The COBOL language underlies critical business systems, but WCA for Z is using the power of AI to help developers understand and modernize it.

item.title: How to know if your AI agents are working as intended
item.description: IBM's AgentOps is a set of tools born out of IBM Research for AI builders and engineers to monitor whether the agents they've built are operating as expected.

item.title: IBM’s Dmitry Krotov wants to crack the ‘physics’ of memory
item.description: Dima Krotov is searching for an AI architecture that is both interpretable and could explain how our own memory works.

item.title: IBM is donating its CBOM toolset to the Linux Foundation
An AI model with a finger on the time series pulse
item.description: IBM’s new foundation model, TSPulse, can go beyond standard forecasting tasks to detect anomalies, fill in missing values, classify data, and search recurring patterns. It’s also tiny enough to run on a laptop.

item.title: IBM Granite tops Hugging Face leaderboard
item.description: IBM's Granite Speech 3.3 8B model is the top of Hugging Face's Open automatic speech recognition leaderboard.

item.title: Celebrating the FFT and the Future of Computing
item.description: The Fast Fourier Transform forever changed the landscape of modern computing. What lessons can it teach us when it comes to quantum algorithm development?

item.title: Introducing IBM's new AI-powered PFAS-screening tool
item.description: The Safer Materials Advisor can cut by up to two thirds the time it takes to review chemical products for PFAS

item.title: How to make AI models more accurate: Embrace failure
item.description: Here's how failed experiments make chemical language models more accurate.

item.title: NAE recognizes T.C. Chen’s role in semiconductor evolution
item.description: In his four decades at IBM Research, T.C. Chen has played a central role in the qualification of generation after generation of semiconductor technologies.

item.title: IBM lays out clear path to fault-tolerant quantum computing
item.description: IBM has developed a detailed framework for achieving large-scale fault-tolerant quantum computing by 2029, and we’re updating our roadmap to match.

item.title: Large memory storage through astrocyte computation
item.description: What a long-overlooked cell in the brain can tell us about cognition and AI architectures.

item.title: How IBM Research first demonstrated the Cooley-Tukey FFT
item.description: It’s the algorithm that made internet videos possible. The Cooley-Tukey Fast Fourier Transform was first demonstrated at IBM Research in 1964.

item.title: New application functions bring quantum to applied research
item.description: Two new additions to the Qiskit Functions Catalog are the latest of many application functions that integrate quantum computing into application workflows.

item.title: The future of AI agent evaluation
item.description: Researchers at Hebrew University, IBM, and Yale summarize the latest in AI agent benchmarking and suggest four ways it could be improved.

item.title: Shedding new light on topological lattices
What is fault-tolerant quantum computing?
item.description: Understanding the basics of quantum error correction and fault tolerance.

item.title: Register today for Qiskit Global Summer School 2025
item.description: Explore the past, present, and future of quantum computing

item.title: An open-source protocol for AI agents to interact
item.description: IBM's Agent Communication Protocol gives AI agents a shared language to connect and collaborate to carry out complex, real-world tasks.

item.title: Lockheed Martin & IBM combine quantum computing with classical HPC in new research
item.description: Researchers conduct chemistry simulations with sample-based quantum diagonalization (SQD), a prime candidate for near-term demonstrations of quantum advantage.

item.title: Learn quantum computing fundamentals on IBM Quantum Learning
item.description: Newly completed series offers an in-depth, university-level intro to quantum computing fundamentals through four online courses.

item.title: A new watermarking method for AI-generated tables
item.description: IBM Research has co-developed a new way to embed ownership information into synthetic tabular data to discourage its misuse.

item.title: Introducing the Quantum Optimization Benchmarking Library
item.description: The Quantum Optimization Working Group presents ten problem classes — an “intractable decathlon” — to enable the search for quantum advantage in optimization.

item.title: Remembering IBM researcher Dick Garwin
item.description: The IBM Fellow Emeritus and longtime presidential advisor passed away at age 97.

item.title: How AI is improving chip production
item.description: IBM Research scientists are using AI to track down defects and inefficiencies in silicon wafer processing.

item.title: A new tool for crediting AI's contributions
item.description: IBM's AI attribution toolkit helps users describe how AI contributed to their work.

item.title: Content aware storage for the generative AI era
item.description: IBM Research and IBM Storage partnered to make a “content aware” storage system, which promises to reshape how businesses leverage their vast data estates.

item.title: What’s next in computing is generative and quantum
item.description: At Think 2025, IBM Research leaders explored generative computing, and outlined that quantum advantage is just around the corner.

item.title: New IBM Quantum Flex Plan enables for project-based research
item.description: The new IBM Quantum access plan lets you conduct high-impact quantum computing research at the pace and scale that best suits your needs.

item.title: ASTER: Natural and multi-language unit test generation with LLMs
Meet Bamba, IBM's new attention-state space model
item.description: The open-source LLM combines the sequence-modeling skill of a transformer with the inferencing speed of an SSM. IBM Granite will soon adopt key Bamba features.

item.title: IEEE medals recognize unexpected computer science methods
item.description: Miklós Ajtai applied pure mathematics to computational problems, and Regina Barzilay adapted language model architecture for early cancer detection.

item.title: Keio University, Mitsubishi Chemical explore quantum utility
item.description: How Quantum Innovation Centers like Keio University in Tokyo are helping large enterprise research organizations explore utility-scale quantum computing.

item.title: Terramind: the new generative AI model for Earth observation
item.description: The new foundation model from IBM and the ESA combines insights from nine types of Earth observation data to provide an intuitive understanding of our planet.

item.title: IBM and UIUC develop an orchestration system to serve LLMs more efficiently
A new LoRA technology for efficient agentic applications
item.description: IBM Research's new "adapted" LoRA can give LLMs specialized capabilities at inference time without the delay.

item.title: Transitioning to quantum-safe communication: Adding Q-safe preference to OpenSSL TLSv1.3
item.description: OpenSSL v3.5 enables TLS clients to send multiple key shares and introduces a new group selection algorithm for servers to address the NSA's ‘prefer’ quantum-safe algorithms mandate in CNSA 2.0.

item.title: Speeding up EV battery development with AI digital twins
item.description: IBM Research’s foundation models are powering simulated versions of complex systems, which promise to accelerate technological progress.

item.title: Granite Guardian tops third-party AI benchmark
item.description: IBM's collection of LLM guardrail models take six of the top 10 spots on the new GuardBench leaderboard.
